content.description:
Avoid the corner chimney and start to it's left. A couple of easy un protected face moves to gain a splitter hand crack for 40 feet (5.9). From here step onto the Spectrum tower proper and climb the crack past the "sentry box" (10c) and up to the bulge. Clip the bolt and move up and right (crux) into the brilliant sustained twin cracks to single finger crack finish. The upper 35 feet protect well (as does the entire route) but the gear placements are pumpy to hang out and place. I really love this climb and to successfully lead it is incredible satisfying. It climbs much better than it looks and is better than Infrared.

It is named after my oldest daughter Violet

Indigo variation TR: Start Infrared and traverse across to Ultraviolet 12b/c
content.protection:
Gear to number 2 camalot. especially small to medium. Chain anchor.

Can only just TR with 60m rope. Can easily walk to top to set up

content.description:
Hard, technical, smeary and insecure arete. One of the clips feels very insecure.

FA story:

Many moons ago Troy Corliss and friend from UC Davis where out for the weekend putting up new routes around 1990. They were in the midst of this route near the end of the day. They had with them a visiting UCD student/climber from Spain. She was cranking up a white gas camping stove when it suddenly bust into flames. The Spanish climber freaked, grabbed the entire stove and hurled it lest it not blow up in her face. Viola! The Spanish Flamethrower

Devious and sustained face climbing. Crux is at the 5th bolt where one would ostensibly make a huge lunge right on piss feet to regain the arete. Finishes in a cool 11b finger crack that is also the end of Ultraviolet.
content.protection: 7 draws and a few cams in the .4"-1" range.

content.description: start for same as arete and move up and over a huge flake/block to gain crack. Climb up well protected crack stemming but trying to avoid the grungy corner/chimney. At the top 10b crux moves left on arcing crack to gain the same anchor as Spanish Flamethrower
